title: The Waters of Amsterdam
author: Jonathan Morris
filename: 208 - The Waters of Amsterdam - Jonathan Morris_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-TITLES:
1. EXT. AMSTERDAM
FX: IT’S SPRING, 1983. TRAMS CLANK PAST, BELLS CLANGING.
TRAFFIC. SEAMLESSLY FOLLOWS ON FROM END OF TV’S ‘ARC OF
INFINITY’.
DOCTOR, TEGAN AND NYSSA WALKING TOWARDS US.
So how exactly did you ‘get the sack’, Tegan?
(LAUGHS) Oh, it’s a long story.
I suspected it might be.
FX: MAN RUSHING UP TO THEM, DODGING PEDESTRIANS.
(FAR OFF, RUNNING, CALLING) Tegan! Tegan!
Do you know that man?
I’m very much afraid that I do.
(CLOSER) Tegan! Wait!
Who is he?
Kyle.
Kyle?
(EMBARRASSED SIGH) My ex.
MUSIC: OPENING THEME.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 3
2. INT. SMALL CAFE
FX: HUBBUB OF HALF A DOZEN CUSTOMERS. COFFEE MACHINE.
(RETURNING) Here. Three coffees and one tea.
FX: HE SETS THEM DOWN AND SITS.
Let’s get one thing straight, Kyle. If this is meant to be some sort of grand romantic gesture to win me back it’s not going to work.
I think I know you well enough, Tegan, to know that.
Then what are you doing here? It can hardly be a coincidence.
It is. How could I have possibly known you’d be here?
My mum might’ve said something, she’s always been soft on you. But it’s not up to me to explain it!
Coincidences do happen, Tegan.
What, out of all the places in all the world, he just happens to rock up in Amsterdam. Yeah, right!
(DRINKING TEA) It’s a small world.
No, it’s not, it’s an enormous one, but with some people even being on the other side of it isn’t far enough!
If you must know, I came here to see the Master.
FX: THE DOCTOR NEARLY DROPS HIS TEA.
What! ?
The Dutch Master. Rembrandt. Look. (FX: RUSTLE OF TOURIST FLYER) There’s a new exhibition opened at the Rijksmuseum.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 4
I didn’t know you had a thing for Rembrandt.
Maybe there’s a lot you don’t know about me.
I know enough.
Can I take a look at that? I’m a bit of an aficionado.
Sure.
FX: FLYER PASSED OVER.
Doctor, perhaps we should...
Go for a stroll. Yes.
Anything Kyle has to say he can say in front of you.
Yes, but... I’d rather not be present when he does.
You two clearly have a lot to talk about.
No we don’t.
Don’t worry, we're not going to leave without you.
You’d better not. Alright, off you go, if you must.
Yes, well, we’ll leave you to... it.
FX: THEY LEAVE. A BEAT.
Go on then. Explain.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 5
Alright, yes, when you did your disappearing act, I asked around to find out where you’d gone, and your mum -
I knew it!
She was worried about you. I was worried about you.
You don’t think me saying that I never wanted to see you again was clear enough?
You were angry.
Too right I was angry. It’s been a month, Kyle, a month since we split up. No, let’s not mince words. A month since I dumped you.
I know, but -
Since then, you’ve turned up at my flat, you’ve phoned me all hours of the night -
I want to talk to you, to make you understand -
We have nothing left to talk about. It’s all been said.
Not by me. I want you to give me a chance to explain.

I’m not interested. You’re not going to make me change my mind. (TRIES TO BE KIND) Look, we’re just not right for each other. It took me a while to see it, but as soon as I did, I thought it was only fair to tell you, straight away.
I know, and I appreciate that...
How was I to know you’d planned to propose? I’m not psychic.
It was meant to be a surprise.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 6
Yes, well, well done, it worked.
I think you won in the ‘surprise’ stakes.
You really didn’t see it coming?
Of course not. I wouldn’t have... if I’d suspected.
We were never that serious, Kyle. That was the whole problem. You were coming on strong all the time.
I can’t help it, Tegan.
Don’t say it.
I love you.

Well, maybe you do. But I don’t love you, and I’m sorry if that makes me a bad person, but it’s over. And the sooner you accept that and move on, the better for both of us. (GETS UP TO GO) Goodbye, Kyle. Have a good life.
FX: SHE LEAVES.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 7
3. EXT. STREET IN AMSTERDAM
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA WALKING, SOME PEDESTRIANS.
Tegan never mentioned a.. boyfriend.
Well, to be fair, she hasn’t really had much of a chance. And if he’s in the past tense, so to speak...
Do you think he could be here by coincidence?
Possibly. After all, Omega bumped into Tegan - these things do happen. Maybe he really has just come to see this Rembrandt exhibition.
NYSSA3: Who is Rembrandt?
He was a painter. Dutch golden age, keen on dramatic lighting effects and grumpy self-portraits.
Don’t tell me, you’ve met him.
No. Well, not yet. Living a non-linear life, one can never be entirely sure.
FX: HE OPENS LEAFLET.
If his work is worth travelling halfway around the world to see, he must have been a remarkable man.
(READING, DISTRACTED, INTRIGUED) Yes, he was. I say...
NYSSA3: What is it?
I recognise most of his work, but I never knew he liked to draw spaceships...
What?
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 8
FX: TEGAN RUNS UP TO THEM, HEELS ON COBBLES.
There you are!
You’ve finished talking to... Kyle?
Yeah. We didn’t have much to say.
3: No?
He wanted me to give him one last chance. I didn’t. (NOTICES LEAFLET) What’s that?
It’s about the exhibition, of Rembrandt’s drawings... of spaceships.
(LAUGHS) You must’ve got him mixed up with Da Vinci.
Who?
Da Vinci.
You mean Leonardo. Nobody ever called him Da Vinci.

Doctor. In the last twenty-four hours, I’ve seen my cousin turned into a zombie, been held hostage by an alien with a henchman that looked suspiciously like a plucked chicken, been on a wild goose chase through Amsterdam, and had my ex- boyfriend turn up out of the blue. The last thing I need is you having a go at me for getting Da Vinci’s name wrong!
Leonardo’s.
Leonardo’s!
Maybe we could, er, go to this ‘Rijkmuseum’?
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 9
Yes. Tegan’s right. Rembrandt didn’t draw spaceships. Something
very strange must be going on.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 10
4. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE RIJKMUSEUM
FX: DOCTOR AND FRIENDS GET OFF TRAM.
DOCTOR/TEGAN/NYSSA:
GETTING OFF TRAM
What if it’s sold out?
We shall just have to charm our way in.
FX: DISTANT THUNDER. BEGINS TO RAIN AS THEY WALK.
(SHIVER) Ugh, great.
Looks like we made it here just in time.
You can say that again. It’s going to be raining cats and dogs in a minute.
This way, I think. (BEAT) Nyssa? Are you alright?
Yes. I thought I saw something in the canal. Just out of the corner of my eye.
What sort of something?
I don’t know. Nothing. Come on. Let’s get inside.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 11
5. INT. GALLERY IN RIJKMUSEUM
FX: RESPECTFUL MURMUR OF TOURISTS.

(ENJOYING THE SOUND OF HIS OWN VOICE) What is truly remarkable about this work is that while Rembrandt fulfils his brief to include the faces of all the members of the militia, he also creates a sense of drama, of movement. You could almost believe this was a real moment frozen in time.
It’s a bit gloomy.

Gloomy? What you are seeing, Tegan, is the artist’s distinctive use of contrapuntal rhythms. You will also note the extensive use of chiaroscuro to bestow a sense of depth, both literally and, of course, psychologically.
It’s very impressive. The faces seem almost alive.
Doctor, what’s ‘chiaroscuro’?
What? Oh, bold contrasting areas of light and dark that suggest three-dimensionality. Leonardo’s innovation, developed by Caravaggio, perfected by Rembrandt. But it’s not what we’ve come to see.
Speaking of things we didn’t come here to see. Over there, by the painting of the woman with the egg basket.
Kyle! He followed us?
Let’s not jump to conclusions. He did say he was coming here.
Nyssa. Do you fancy getting a coffee?
Well, actually, I just had one -
I mean, do you fancy keeping me company while I hide in the cafe downstairs?
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 12
Of course. Doctor? (HE’S NOT PAYING ATTENTION) Doctor?
Oh leave him, he’s miles away.
FX: TEGAN AND NYSSA LEAVE DURING THE FOLLOWING:

Of course, what’s ingenious is Rembrandt’s use of colour - not only for emphasis, but also as a signifier; the red of the Captain’s sash against his black and white costume represents the city’s colours, while the blue and gold of the girl represents the company’s coat of arms.
FX: DURING THIS, TOURISTS HAVE GATHERED.
What about the fella with the drum?
I’m sorry?
You are a tour guide, aren’t you? So. What about the fella with the drum?
Ah. Well. Yes. I’m very glad you asked me that, actually, because, of course, a drummer wouldn’t have been able to afford to have his portrait painted...
FADE OUT DURING THE ABOVE.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 13
6. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
FX: POLITE CONVERSATIONS IN B/G. BUSY.
(SIPS COFFEE) Lucky to get a table. I guess nobody’s keen on going outside and getting themselves soaked.
So are you going to tell me?
Tell you what?
About Kyle. You don’t have to, of course.

No, you might as well know. I met him about a year ago now. After you and the Doctor left me at Heathrow, I took up my job as a stewardess for Air Antipodes. It was on one of the flights I first met him.
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 14
7. INT. BOEING 747
FX: GENERAL CHATTER WHICH FALLS SILENT AFTER DING-DONG.
(VOICE AND VIA TANNOY )

Ladies and gentlemen. We will shortly be coming in to land at Sydney Airport. Please could all passengers extinguish any cigarettes, return your seats to a locked and upright position, and check your seat belts are fastened. Thank you.
FX: DING-DONG.
(MAKING HIS WAY ALONG AISLE) Excuse me.
Sir, you will have to return to your seat.
Out of my way, I have an urgent meeting, I have to be the first off!
Sir, we’ll be on the ground in a few minutes.
I said, young woman, out of my way!
Please return to your seat, sir.
You don’t tell me what to do -
On this plane I do. So sit!
Hey, mate, maybe you should do as she says.
This is none of your business, “mate”.
Sorry, just trying to help the lady -
This “lady” doesn’t need your help.
(PUSHING HER) Get... out...
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 15
Hey! Don’t push.
Leave her alone!
I said this is none of your business. (SWINGS A PUNCH)
WHACKED
FX: HE FALLS, CLATTER OF SEAT TRAY, PASSENGERS REACT, MIXTURE
OF HORROR AND DELIGHT.
OW! MORE SHOCKED THAN HURT
Now, let me pass!
Alright, you asked for it. (KICKS ON ‘IT’)
FX: SHE KICKS BUSINESSMAN IN THE SHIN.
Oy! My shin! I can’t believe it! There’s going to be a bruise!
You should count yourself lucky I didn’t aim higher.
This is assault. I warn you, I intend to contact the airline and lodge a formal complaint.
Do whatever you like, just get back in your seat.
(RETURNING TO HIS SEAT) You haven’t heard the last of this, you can be certain of that.
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 16
8. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
And that’s how I lost my job.
It doesn’t sound very fair.
I don’t think I was cut out for it. Being polite to complete idiots, not really my strong point.
No.
So I was given my marching orders, and who do I find waiting
for me outside the office?
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 17
9. INT. SYDNEY AIRPORT BUILDING
FX: PLANES TAKING OFF/LANDING IN B/G.
What are you doing here?
I’ve come to explain that it wasn’t your fault, what happened, that he punched me first.
I thought I told you, I can fight my own battles. Anyway, you’re too late. I’ve been fired.
What? Then I should definitely go in, and -
Don’t you dare. The guy’s agreed to drop his complaint if I go, while I get three months’ pay and a glowing reference.
So no regrets?
I don’t know. I wish I’d poured a drink over his head while I had the chance.
(LAUGHS) Speaking of drinks, could I buy you one? If you don’t have any other plans?
Not for the next three months, no.
Well, then. Give me a chance to apologise.
You have nothing to apologise for. What you did, I suppose it was... quite sweet.
Alright. To celebrate, your change of career.
That sounds more like it. What’s your name, by the way?
FX: THEY WALK AWAY TOGETHER.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 18
Kyle.
I’m Tegan. So, what do you do?
Oh, imports, exports, all very dull...
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 19
10. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
So we went for a drink, we got on okay, but I thought that was
that. And then —
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 20
11. INT. SYDNEY SHOPPING CENTRE
FX: MUZAK. ESCALATORS. SHOPPERS.
Tegan!
Kyle, what are you doing here?
Just doing a bit of shopping on my lunch break. You?
What else does one do in a shopping centre?
Ah. Yes. Good point.
I mean, I don’t mean to be rude, but -
Tell you what, why don’t we grab a coffee. Unless you’re meeting someone or -
No, I’m not meeting anyone. (SOFTENS) Oh, alright. One coffee. What’s the worst that could happen?
FX: THEY WALK AWAY.
Do you fancy trying the new Italian place, they do cappuccinos, espressos -
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 21
12. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
I didn’t really think anything of it, it was nice to see him, but then it started happening more and more. We just kept bumping into each other for some reason. Like it was fate.
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 22
13. INT. INDIAN RESTAURANT
FX: INDIAN MUSIC FROM A 70S BOLLYWOOD MUSICAL.
Tegan?!
Kyle. What are you doing here?
(AT THE SAME TIME AS TEGAN) What are you doing here? (THEY BOTH
You first.
It’s a bit embarrassing, but I was supposed to be, ah, meeting someone. Only she hasn’t turned up.
A girlfriend?
More of a first date. Or not, as it turns out.
Join the club.
What?
I’ve been stood up.
Oh. I’m sorry to hear that.
You don’t sound very sorry.
Well, I just thought, I don’t fancy walking back to an empty flat with my tail between my legs, we do have a table booked, would you fancy maybe keeping me company?
You mean, have dinner?
If you don’t mind?
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 23
No. You see, I’m pleased that your date didn’t turn up too.
I never said I was pleased.
Yeah, but you are, though, aren’t you?
A bit. Yes. We’ll just have to show them what they were
missing, won’t we?
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 24
14. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
I mean, he was nice. Charming, in a way.
I saw him, he’s very good-looking.
If you like that sort of thing. Which, I admit, I do.
LAUGHS
I had a Paul Newman poster on my bedroom wall, alright!
So you started seeing each other?
Just as friends. You know, someone to go to the cinema with, someone to take to a party -
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
15. INT. KITCHEN
FX: A PARTY. CHAT, LAUGHTER. TEGAN AND KYLE ARE IN KITCHEN SO
PARTY NOISE COMES AND GOES AS PEOPLE ENTER AND LEAVE TO FETCH DRINKS.
I still don’t know what it is you do.
It’s really quite magnificently dull.
Yes, but you must have a job title. How high up are you?
Fairly high-ish.
Fairly high-ish?
It’s my own business. So I’m sort of the managing director.
And what exactly do you import and export?
Luxury cars. Speedboats, yachts -
Kyle. Are you loaded?
Well, it depends. You haven’t seen my flat, have you?
No.
Beulah St Wharf. View of the bridge, the opera house. Open invitation, anytime you want.
I might just take you up on that.
So what did you do, before you became a stewardess?
Oh, nothing much.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26
Nothing much?
I travelled. With a couple of friends.
Did you go anywhere nice?
(LAUGHS) Very, very rarely.
So who were they, these friends of yours?
Oh, it doesn’t matter. I’m never going to see them again.
You might. I mean -
No. It was like another life. Never to return. Can we talk about something else?
We could dance.
I don’t dance. Well, I do a mean Charleston, but, no. There is one thing I’m good at, though.
What?
This. (SHE KISSES HIM)
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
16. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
So we started dating. It was fun at first, I mean, he could afford all the finest restaurants, front row seats at the theatre.
That’s not really a reason for seeing someone.
I know... but it doesn’t hurt. And he was fun too. A laugh, you know. Didn’t take himself too seriously.
So what went wrong?
Hard to say. It’s not like someone flicked a switch. It sounds like a cliché... but I think the problem wasn’t with him, it was with me.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
17. INT. GALLERY IN RIJKMUSEUM
FX: A CROWD HAS GATHERED AROUND THE DOCTOR.

So the trees in the distance are caught in the light, while the figures nearby are hidden in shadow and almost impressionistic, capturing not just the sunset, but the very atmosphere of the moment. And that, I would suggest, was Rembrandt’s genius.
FX: CROWD APPLAUDS THEN DISPERSES.
(APPROACHING) You’re quite the expert, Doctor.
Not really. It’s just a question of saying what you see. If you’re looking for Tegan, she’s not here.
I thought, if I came all this way, she might let me explain, but...
Yes. Tegan’s not the easiest person to explain to, in my experience.
We were happy for two months. And then it all started to go wrong.
I'd gathered.
No matter what I did, no matter how hard I tried to be the man she wanted, she just seemed to get more and more irritated.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
18. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
He just got more and more irritating.
But why?
Because... he was too nice. Too perfect.
3: That doesn’t make sense.
I’m not claiming it does, it’s just that everything he did was whatever he thought I wanted. He never thought for himself. It drove me up the wall!
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
19. EXT. KYLE’S FLAT
FX: A BALCONY AT NIGHT. TOOTS AND CHUGS AS BOATS GO BY.
You’re going to have to take them back.
But you said you wanted to go to the concert, I checked.
I know, you weren’t very subtle.
What’s the matter, don’t you like Elton John?
It’s not that. I can’t have you spending money on me all the time. It.. puts me in your debt.
But I want to buy you things.
But I don’t want you to! I don’t need you to. Look. I know I’m being unreasonable, but -
It’s alright. I don’t mind. I forgive you!
(AAARGH!) That’s just it! You should be angry! You should be... putting your foot down. You never fight back!
But why would I want to do that?
Because I’m not always right and I need someone to tell me when I’m wrong!
I’m sorry -
And stop apologising! (BEAT, THEN TO HERSELF) Good grief.
I just thought, you know, the concert’s six months away, if I didn’t get them now, it would sell out.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
Yeah, but what makes you think we’1ll still be together?
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
20. INT. STAIRWELL IN RIJKMUSEUM
It seemed that nothing I did would please her.
I know the feeling. (READS SIGN) ‘Special collection’. Up here.
FX: THEY CLIMB STAIRS.
What do you mean?
Some people are only happy when they have something to complain about.
That doesn’t make sense.
Yes, well. You know Tegan better than me.
I thought I did. But it turns out I didn’t know her at all.
FX: INTO FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
21. EXT. KYLE’S FLAT
I said, what makes you think we’ll still be together?
Well, this isn’t quite the moment I had in mind, I was going to ask you tonight at the restaurant, but.. well...
Oh no, don’t you dare! Don’t you dare get down on one knee!
What?
This isn’t what I want. If you knew me at all, Kyle, you’d know this was the complete opposite!
I’m not a mind-reader.
No, you’re not. That’s abundantly clear. It’s a pity. Because... if you were, it would save me having to say what I’m about to say.
FX: OUT OF FLASHBACK.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 34
22. INT. RIJKMUSEUM CAFE
GROWING DISQUIET IN B/G, FX: PEOPLE GETTING UP TO LEAVE
I know I handled it badly. But... all that time, I never really knew him.
It sounds like he didn’t really know you.
I could never be honest with him. I never told him about the TARDIS, and you and the Doctor.
Would he have believed you?
Probably. That’s the thing. He’d hang on my every word. Sometimes I’d even lie to him just to see if he’d notice. Nothing. (REACTS) Ugh!
What is it?
My feet, they’re wet.. the floor, it’s flooded!
IN B/G, THEY HAVE A SIMILAR REACTION
NYSSA3: There must be a leak somewhere.
You don’t say.
FX: FOOTSTEPS, SPLASHING. PEOPLE ARE LEAVING.
It’s getting deeper. Where’s it all coming from?
We can’t hang around here. Come on. Let’s find the Doctor.
FX: THEY LEAVE
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 35
23. INT. STAIRWELL IN RIJKMUSEUM
FX: THEY’RE WALKING UP STAIRS. RAIN LASHING ON WINDOWS.
Ah. Here we are. “Special collection”.
FX: THEY PASS THROUGH DOORS. QUIET, CARPETED ROOM.
I say this is most interesting. Are you actually interested in Rembrandt, at all?
A little. I’ve dealt in art, paintings in the past.
Did you know he drew spaceships?
No.
So it’s not general knowledge. (TO HIMSELF) A new development.
What?
Take a look at that sketch, dated 1658. Anything strike you as odd?
It’s not in his normal style. I mean, it’s highly detailed, but more like a.. schematic diagram.
Precisely. That’s what these are. You see that? That’s a gravity warp drive. And that? That’s a focus resonator.
I don’t understand.
Nor do I, not yet. But not only has Rembrandt been drawing blueprints of spaceships, but if somebody followed them, they would actually work!
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 36
24. INT. MODERN ART GALLERY IN RIJKMUSEUM
FX: WE ENTER WITH TEGAN AND NYSSA. RAIN LASHING ON WINDOWS.
CLOSES BEHIND THEM, MUFFLING STORM.
What’s all this?
“Modern art”.
Sculptures?
If you can call them that. Not really my sort of thing.
No?
I prefer it when you look at something, you can tell what it 16%
FX: THEY PAUSE BY A TRICKLING WATER FEATURE.
Some of the sculptures are quite ingenious, though. This statue, for instance.
What about it? It’s just a goblin or demon or something.
But look at it. It appears to be made out of running water.
It’s just glass. There’1ll be an explanation on the card.
3: What card?
There’s always a white card, by the floor, saying what it’s called and who made it.
Tegan. There isn’t a white card.
What, but there must be -
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 37
FX: STATUE MOVES, SPLOSHING EFFECT.
SURPRISED
Nyssa?
It moved. It tried to reach out and grab me. (FX: IT MOVES AGAIN, MORE SPLOSHING) It’s alive!
(GURGLING ALIEN VOICE, INDECIPHERABLE BABBLE - LIKE SOMEONE GARGLING, TALKING UNDERWATER. MENACING, BELLIGERENT — WOKEN UP IN A MEAN MOOD)
FX: STATUE MOVES AGAIN, WALKING. SPLOSH! SPLOSH!
I don’t know what it is, but it’s not one of the exhibits. Run!
FX: THEY RUN. THE CREATURE LURCHES AFTER THEM.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 38
25. INT. STAIRWELL IN RIJKMUSEUM
FX: RAIN LASHING ON WINDOWS, RUMBLES OF THUNDER.
But how could Rembrandt know how a spaceship worked?
That’s just it. He couldn’t.
FX: TEGAN AND NYSSA RUNNING UP STAIRS.
(CALLS OUT) Doctor!
Tegan, Nyssa, what is it?
We’re being followed.
Followed?
By some sort of creature made out of water!
What did you say?
Oh, you’re here.
I wasn’t following you if that’s what you - [were]
FX: SLOSHING OF NIX APPROACHING.
AGGRESSIVE
NYSSA3: Down there!
Yes, I see it. Most extraordinary.
What in heaven’s name is that?
I have absolutely no idea, but it’s coming this way.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 39
I have an idea. (FX: GRABS A FIRE EXTINGUISHER)
A fire extinguisher? Great plan. It’s made of water, bozo.

POLSBROEK: There are always accidents. Careless individuals. I fail to see how it’s my responsibility.
NYSSA: We’re telling the truth!
POLSBROEK: That remains to be seen. You do not dress like citizens of this city, nor do you speak like them.
TEGAN: Look, we’re not spies, if that’s what you’re getting at.
POLSBROEK: No?
TEGAN: We stick out a mile. Wouldn’t a couple of spies try to blend in?
NYSSA: And who are we supposed to be spying for? I thought you were at peace?
NYSSA: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 66
POLSBROEK: We are. But there is trouble brewing in Zealand and we may soon be obliged to defend the Danes. And, while the English are busily engaged in war with Spain, they remain our greatest rivals.. and we understand your ‘Lord Protector’ may not be long for this world.
TEGAN: He’s not our Lord Protector. We’re not English.
POLSBROEK: Then where are you from?
TEGAN: I’m from Australia.
POLSBROEK: “Australia”?
TEGAN: (CORRECTING HERSELF) New Holland.
POLSBROEK: I have read Tasman’s reports of the place. A desolate, inhospitable island by all accounts.
TEGAN: That’s about right.
POLSBROEK: So how do you come to be here?
TEGAN: Does it matter? Look, if we were spies, wouldn’t we come up with a more likely story?
POLSBROEK: If you were spies, you would say anything to deflect suspicion, even pretending to be touched by madness. And you, girl. Where are you from?
NYSSA: 3: You would never believe me.
POLSBROEK: Then you shall have to convince me, girl. Because I am determined to get to the truth - one way or another.
POLSBROEK: Captain Glauber?
POLSBROEK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 67
GLAUBER: Yes, sir?
POLSBROEK: Would you be so kind as to fetch the instruments of torture?
POLSBROEK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)
POLSBROEK: Page 68
KYLE: (READING STREET SIGN) Jodenbreestraat, this is it.
DOCTOR: Let’s hope there’s somebody at home. Hopefully Nyssa and Tegan
DOCTOR: will have prepared the way.
REMBRANDT: (OTHER SIDE OF DOOR)
REMBRANDT: I’m coming, I’m coming, must I never get any peace!
REMBRANDT: Yes?
DOCTOR: Rembrandt Van Rijn?
REMBRANDT: Yes, what, what?
DOCTOR: Excellent. I wonder, have you met two of my friends,
DOCTOR: women, called Tegan and Nyssa?
REMBRANDT: What is this? A joke?
DOCTOR: No joke, I can -
REMBRANDT: two young
REMBRANDT: You disturb me, in the middle of my work, to ask about lost
REMBRANDT: women? No, I haven’t seen them, nor do I wish to!
KYLE: Tegan and Nyssa, if they’re not here...
DOCTOR: With any luck they’ve gone back to the
DOCTOR: find them, once we’re done here.
DOCTOR: TARDIS. We’1ll go and
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 69
REMBRANDT: What is it, you damnable fellow! Can’t you see I’m busy!
DOCTOR: Sorry to interrupt. Wondered if we might have a word.
REMBRANDT: A word? I have a word for you, sir. And that word is good-day!
DOCTOR: Wait! It’s vitally important we speak to you. Tonight.
REMBRANDT: You can tell Boelissen and Witsen that they’1ll get no more out of me till the auction. They might as well try and squeeze blood out of a stone!
DOCTOR: We’re not debt collectors.
REMBRANDT: Then what are you? Bailiffs?
DOCTOR: No, I can assure you, we’re not after money or property.
REMBRANDT: Then why are you here? (PEERS AT DOCTOR) You’re too old for me to take on as an apprentice. Go and bother Van Der Helst, he’1ll tell you which end of the brush to point at the canvas.
DOCTOR: No, we just want to -
REMBRANDT: You want to commission me to paint your portrait? Hmmm. Let me see. Pleasant open face... eyebrows will be tricky, though.
DOCTOR: No, much as I would love to have my portrait painted -
REMBRANDT: What then? A biblical scene? A landscape? I should let you know, I draw the line at fancy-women and dogs. And if it’s a group portrait, I charge per face! No extra family members sneaking in at the back!
DOCTOR: I just want to talk.
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 70
REMBRANDT: To talk? The damnable fellow wants to talk! What about?
DOCTOR: Your work.
REMBRANDT: You disturb me in the middle of my work to talk to me... about my work?
DOCTOR: I’m very sorry if it’s a bad time.
REMBRANDT: It’s always a bad time. Good-day!
KYLE: But we have travelled a long way, and it would be a great honour. We’re both huge admirers of your work.
REMBRANDT: What is this? Some game?
KYLE: Not at all. The way you use chiaroscuro to suggest three- dimensionality is quite extraordinary.
DOCTOR: And the way you achieve unity of composition is quite simply breathtaking.
REMBRANDT: You know, nobody ever mentions that, and I spend hours getting it right. You are clearly a connoisseur, Mv...
DOCTOR: Doctor.
REMBRANDT: Come in, then, if you’re coming. And your friend...
KYLE: Kyle.
REMBRANDT: Kyle. Your voice... I thought I recognised it. But your face is unfamiliar.
KYLE: You must be thinking of someone else.
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 71
REMBRANDT: Yes, I must... Well, don’t dawdle on the doorstep, come in and
REMBRANDT: tell me how great I am!
REMBRANDT: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 72
TEGAN: You can’t torture us, we’re innocent civilians!
POLSBROEK: On the contrary, you are suspected agents of a foreign power. have every right to cross-examine you by any means necessary.
NYSSA: But even if we tell you the truth, you won’t believe us.
POLSBROEK: So you haven’t been telling the truth so far? I thought as much. So where are you from?
TEGAN: Nyssa, no -
NYSSA: I am from a world called Traken and my friend is from Earth three centuries in your future.
POLSBROEK: (SIGH) Well, why didn’t you say so straight away? It would’ve saved a great deal of unnecessary unpleasantness!
TEGAN: I’m sorry, what?
POLSBROEK: Your arrival was not unexpected. Please, come with me.
TEGAN: Where to?
POLSBROEK: The Countess has a chamber on the top floor. She’s very eager to meet you.
POLSBROEK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 73
CREAKY: WOODEN-FLOORED ROOM; TIDYING MATERIALS, OPENING DRAWERS,
LIGHTING: LAMPS, UNCORKING SOME WINE.
REMBRANDT: Please, sit down, sit down. Forgive the clutter.
DOCTOR: Quite a collection you’ve got here. Is that a Raphael?
REMBRANDT: It is. Over the decades I have acquired works by every major artist, glass from Venice...
KYLE: Are you having some sort of clear out?
REMBRANDT: In a manner of speaking. Everything here is for auction. Most of my possessions have already been sold to pay my creditors.
DOCTOR: I’m very sorry to hear that.
REMBRANDT: Yes, but sympathy does not put food on the table, it doesn’t buy me oils or canvas.
DOCTOR: I didn’t mean -
REMBRANDT: They even threaten to take this house, my pride and joy. So, I must make sacrifices.
DOCTOR: Some of these paintings are your own work.
REMBRANDT: Unwanted commissions. Ten years ago, I could charge five hundred guilders a painting. Now I’1l be lucky if any of these go for over twenty.
KYLE: But why?
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 74
REMBRANDT: I am out of fashion. The “new Flemish” style! Nowadays people just want hunting scenes, and still lifes of whatever they’re about to have for breakfast.
DOCTOR: This may be an impertinent question, but how did you end up in this predicament?
REMBRANDT: You ask me how? Like it was my choice, my decision?
DOCTOR: No, not at all.
REMBRANDT: Not as a result of my own greed, if that’s what you were thinking. I know the stories that have been going around. No. I have been brought down by thieves and liars. They commission me to paint their wives and mistresses, but when the time comes to pay, they say they can’t afford to, they say they’ve gone bankrupt!
DOCTOR: Ah. I see.
REMBRANDT: Is it my fault they’ve lost all their money on the stock market, investing in tulips! Tulips, would you believe! I have worked every day of my life to put bread on the table to feed my wife and son, why should I suffer for the foolishness of others? Tulips!
KYLE: Where are they, your wife and son?
REMBRANDT: My son is studying in Leiden. Saskia... is dead.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry to hear that.
REMBRANDT: And now I am left, scrabbling for pennies. If not for the Countess I would be begging on the street!
DOCTOR: The Countess?
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 75
FORCEFIELD: GENERATOR IN B/G, THROB OF POWER.
POLSBROEK: Countess, the two time-travellers.
TELDAK: Bring them to me.
TEGAN: (QUIET) I get the impression she’s not from round here either.
NYSSA: (QUIET) What make you think that? The golden skin or the sapphire compound eyes?
POLSBROEK: This woman is called Tegan and is from the future. This woman is called Nyssa and is from a world called Traken.
TELDAK: Fascinating. Thank you for bringing them to me, Mayor Polsbroek.
POLSBROEK: There is a third visitor, a man called the Doctor.
TELDAK: And where is he?
POLSBROEK: His whereabouts are unknown, but the watch have been informed -
TELDAK: I see. You may return to your duties.
POLSBROEK: As you wish, Countess.
TELDAK: (TO NYSSA) Traken. I have not heard of it.
NYSSA: There’s no reason why you should. It’s very distant from this world.
NYSSA: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 76
TELDAK: It is? But so is my home.
TEGAN: And where’s that?
TELDAK: Corus-Valletine. You will not have heard of it. Please tell me, how do you travel in time?
TEGAN: Not until you tell us what you’re doing here.
TELDAK: Your.. caution is justifiable. I am the Countess Mach-Teldak, first born of the imperial dynasty and rightful heir to the Voraxi throne.
NYSSA: Then why are you here?
TELDAK: My world was attacked by a species known as the Nix.
NYSSA: The Nix?!
TELDAK: They made it rain for a whole year. Our cities and towns were inundated. We had no choice but to flee.
NYSSA: So you came here?
TELDAK: The Nix pursued my flame-ship across the stars. My ship was damaged, and I was forced to teleport to the nearest planet before it disintegrated. I had hoped the Nix would think me dead and abandon their pursuit.
TEGAN: Well that hasn’t worked. They’re here in this city.
TELDAK: I am aware of that. They will stop at nothing until they have executed all of my kind.
TEGAN: They want you dead?
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 77
TELDAK: And to get to me they will kill anyone that stands in their
TELDAK: way.
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 78
RATTLING: WINDOWS, SHUTTERS CREAKING IN WIND.
DOCTOR: She is the one who hired you to draw spaceships?
REMBRANDT: “Vessels of the stars”. Not my usual line of work but she was willing to pay and I was unwilling to starve.
DOCTOR: But you don’t know how they work?
REMBRANDT: No, no, my job is simply to follow the instructions.
DOCTOR: Instructions given to you by the Countess?
REMBRANDT: By her representative. I have never actually met her, but I believe she... appreciates my talents.
DOCTOR: She must do, to take the greatest painter of the age and employ him as a draughtsman.
REMBRANDT: Greatest painter? You really think so?
DOCTOR: Wait. Have any of these vessels of the stars actually been built?
REMBRANDT: One is in the process of construction, down at the East India Wharf. It should be complete in the next few days.
REMBRANDT: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 79
NYSSA: And when it’s finished, you intend to leave?
TELDAK: Some more components are required, focusing carbon lattices, but Polsbroek is working on that.
TEGAN: So what’s in it for him?
TELDAK: The same thing that is “in it” for the rest of humanity. While I remain here, this city, this world is not safe.
NYSSA: Do the Nix know where you are?
TELDAK: I have remained hidden, by means of a genetic shield... but your arrival will not have gone undetected.
TEGAN: You can say that again, one of those things attacked us -
TELDAK: And they will try to use you, to get at me.
TEGAN: You mean, they’ll have followed us... (YELP) Ah.
TEGAN: NYSSA3: What is it?
TEGAN: Cold water, on the back of my neck.
NYSSA: The wall drapes. They’re wet. Soaked!
TEGAN: It must be seeping through from outside.
TELDAK: The Nix are attempting to enter. I must summon the watch!
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 80
SPLOSH: AS IT APPROACHES.
TEGAN: Too late.
TEGAN: NYSSA3: There’s more of them -
NIX: Where is the Countess?
NYSSA: What?
NIX: Where is the Countess Mach-Teldak? Where!
TEGAN: (SOTTO) They can’t see her!
NYSSA: (SOTTO) The ‘genetic shield’. They don’t know she’s here.
NIX: If she is in this chamber, she will reveal herself. Or both of these women will die!
TELDAK: Leave the women. I am the one you want.
NIX: You are Mach-Teldak of Corus-Valletine?
TELDAK: I am.
NIX: You have been sentenced to execution.
TELDAK: I am a highborn. We do not fear death.
NIX: Good. Your elimination will be swift.

TEGAN: Can’t we help her?

FX: DOOR OPENS.

Nyssa.

.What she said. Chiaroscuro.

51. INT. REMBRANDT’S HOUSE LIVING ROOM [CONTINUOUS]
FX: REMBRANDT POTTERS ABOUT.
I think I may have a few blankets left upstairs. If not, you’re welcome to use the sheets covering the furniture, such as it is:
FX: HE HEADS UPSTAIRS, CREAKING WITH EVERY STEP.
Well, he wasn’t very friendly, was he?
He let us in.
Yes, but he didn’t have to be so miserable about it.
FX: THEY PULL UP CHAIRS AND SIT.
He has money troubles. That’s why he agreed to work for the Countess.
Why you hired him on her behalf.
Yes, Doctor. What made you realise?
Rembrandt recognised your voice but not your face. Which is interesting, and I speak as someone who’s had more faces than most.
Yes, well, it’s a long story.
Then start.
My name is Kylex-Twelve, servant of the Countess Mach-Teldak. When our planet was besieged by the Nix, I helped her to escape.
And when her ship was damaged, you teleported to Earth?
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 91
I did. I helped her establish herself in this civilisation and conceal herself from the Nix.
Can we skip this and get to the bit where you ask me out under false pretences?
After the Countess was marooned on this planet, she set in motion the means of her departure. I hired Rembrandt to design a spaceship while she convinced the Mayor to finance its construction.
But if she used it to escape, the Nix would attack it, it would never leave the atmosphere.
So the Countess had another plan. She instructed me to search the Earth for other extra-terrestrial visitors.
So she could hitch a ride?
I left the Countess... a month ago, relatively speaking. And I walked the Earth for the next three centuries, looking for any visitors with the capacity for time-travel.
And that’s what led you to Tegan.
I’d almost given up hope until I was on a flight to Sydney and detected a temporal energy signature.
Me.
A side-effect of TARDIS-travel, you may have picked up a few harmless exotic particles along the way.
Now you tell me!
So once I’d identified you as the... source, I conducted a basic scan of your mind, your physical and psycho-social preferences, to make myself amenable to you.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 92
You did what?
I conducted a basic scan -
You looked inside my head? You poked around my memories just to find out what kinds of blokes I liked? Just so you could get a ride in the TARDIS?
I thought that if you had travelled in time before, it was probable that you would do so again.

And once Tegan led you to me, you mentioned Rembrandt’s drawings so I’d want to pop back in time to investigate. (REALISES) Of course! The Nix weren’t trying to stop me at all, were they? They were trying to stop you!
So you were programmed to act like you were in love with Tegan, to gain her confidence?
No. I wasn’t acting.
What?
From the very first moment I saw you, I knew that I loved you. Not because it was part of my mission, or I was programmed to. I fell in love. It wasn’t meant to happen.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 93
52. INT. COUNTESS’S CHAMBER
FX: UNROLLING SCHEMATIC DIAGRAMS.
The craft at the East India Wharf will serve as a prototype.
But its mechanisms are a complete mystery to us.
Your scholars will soon grasp the scientific principles. Your species is only a few centuries from making these discoveries for itself.
A few centuries! So.. you intend to leave us this knowledge as some sort of parting gift?
Not quite. In my absence, you will construct more such vessels. A whole fleet.
But with such craft... no force could defy us. The East India Company would be the greatest power on Earth! But you won’t be around to witness any of this.

How could we, after you have given us so much?
FX: KNOCK AT DOOR.
Enter.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Countess, Mayor. The Arquebusiers have found an... unusual object
in the corner of Dam Square.

A wooden structure. It defies all attempts to open it.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 94
Have it brought here. I wish to examine it for myself.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 95
53. INT. REMBRANDT’S HOUSE LIVING ROOM
FX: FIRESIDE CRACKLING WARMLY. DOOR QUIETLY OPENS.
Kyle’s trying to talk to Tegan. She doesn’t want to listen.

Yes. The situation is... complicated.
Doctor. You told me Kyle was human.

You couldn’t trust me to keep it secret?

An android trying to pass as human. Overcompensating.
Doctor. Can Kyle really be in love with her?
Because he’s an android, you mean?
Well, yes.
He seems to be under the impression he can.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 96
But what if it was just part of his programming, what if he had no choice in the matter?
Do any of us have any choice who we fall in love with? — I suppose it could be, but what if it is?
Then you can correct it. He can be re-programmed not to love her.
That’s not for me to decide.
You mean you’re not going to do anything?
FX: DOCTOR FINISHES POKING FIRE.
None of my business. I have other matters to attend to.
FX: HE STRAIGHTENS UP, OPENS EXTERIOR DOOR.
Where are you going?
To see the Countess. I gather she’s expecting a lift.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 97
54. INT. REMBRANDT’S HOUSE GUEST BEDROOM
I told you, I don’t want to talk.
(MUFFLED) Then I’1l stay here all night. Just let me say my piece, then I’ll go.
FX: TEGAN OPENS DOOR.
I’1ll hold you to that.
FX: KYLE ENTERS, DOOR CLOSED.
I owe you an apology.
You don’t say.
I’m sorry I lied to you. I was scared, I suppose, that if I told you the truth, you’d want nothing more to do with me.
Well, you got that much right.
But I wanted to tell you. Because I -
Kyle, let me tell you something. You don’t love me, because if you did, you would’ve been honest with me. That’s what love is.
You didn’t tell me the truth.

And that’s why I knew that I didn’t love you. Because I was pretending to be someone I’m not. You’re not in love if you’re play-acting. And you can’t expect someone to fall in love with you, if all you’re doing is spinning them a yarn.
Maybe we could make a fresh start?
It’s too late. You’re a robot, for goodness’ sake.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 98
My positronic brain is seventy times more complex than the human brain. Any emotion you can feel, I can feel.
When will you get it into your head, you don’t love me! You just think you do. It’s like... you’ve got your wires crossed.
I wish it was that simple.
Can’t you just reprogramme yourself to forget about me?

people

KYLE: No. I wasn’t acting.
TEGAN: What?
KYLE: From the very first moment I saw you, I knew that I loved you. Not because it was part of my mission, or I was programmed to. I fell in love. It wasn’t meant to happen.
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 93
TELDAK: The craft at the East India Wharf will serve as a prototype.
POLSBROEK: But its mechanisms are a complete mystery to us.
TELDAK: Your scholars will soon grasp the scientific principles. Your species is only a few centuries from making these discoveries for itself.
POLSBROEK: A few centuries! So.. you intend to leave us this knowledge as some sort of parting gift?
TELDAK: Not quite. In my absence, you will construct more such vessels. A whole fleet.
POLSBROEK: But with such craft... no force could defy us. The East India Company would be the greatest power on Earth! But you won’t be around to witness any of this.
TELDAK: The knowledge that you will continue my work will be enough. You - and your descendants. Do not forget me.
POLSBROEK: How could we, after you have given us so much?
TELDAK: Enter.
GLAUBER: Countess, Mayor. The Arquebusiers have found an... unusual object
GLAUBER: in the corner of Dam Square.
TELDAK: What manner of “unusual object”?
GLAUBER: A wooden structure. It defies all attempts to open it.
GLAUBER: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 94
TELDAK: Have it brought here. I wish to examine it for myself.
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 95
NYSSA: Kyle’s trying to talk to Tegan. She doesn’t want to listen.
DOCTOR: Yes. The situation is... complicated.
NYSSA: Doctor. You told me Kyle was human.
DOCTOR: Yes. A white lie.
NYSSA: You couldn’t trust me to keep it secret?
DOCTOR: I didn’t want to put you in the position of having to lie to your best friend.
NYSSA: So you lied to me.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry. The scan revealed Kyle’s brain was made of positronic circuitry.
NYSSA: And the ‘mirroring’ you observed -
DOCTOR: An android trying to pass as human. Overcompensating.
NYSSA: Doctor. Can Kyle really be in love with her?
DOCTOR: Because he’s an android, you mean?
NYSSA: Well, yes.
DOCTOR: He seems to be under the impression he can.
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 96
NYSSA: But what if it was just part of his programming, what if he had no choice in the matter?
DOCTOR: Do any of us have any choice who we fall in love with? — I suppose it could be, but what if it is?
NYSSA: Then you can correct it. He can be re-programmed not to love her.
DOCTOR: That’s not for me to decide.
NYSSA: You mean you’re not going to do anything?
DOCTOR: None of my business. I have other matters to attend to.
NYSSA: Where are you going?
DOCTOR: To see the Countess. I gather she’s expecting a lift.
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 97
TEGAN: I told you, I don’t want to talk.
KYLE: (MUFFLED) Then I’1l stay here all night. Just let me say my piece, then I’ll go.
TEGAN: I’1ll hold you to that.
KYLE: I owe you an apology.
TEGAN: You don’t say.
KYLE: I’m sorry I lied to you. I was scared, I suppose, that if I told you the truth, you’d want nothing more to do with me.
TEGAN: Well, you got that much right.
KYLE: But I wanted to tell you. Because I -
TEGAN: Kyle, let me tell you something. You don’t love me, because if you did, you would’ve been honest with me. That’s what love is.
KYLE: You didn’t tell me the truth.
TEGAN: And that’s why I knew that I didn’t love you. Because I was pretending to be someone I’m not. You’re not in love if you’re play-acting. And you can’t expect someone to fall in love with you, if all you’re doing is spinning them a yarn.
KYLE: Maybe we could make a fresh start?
TEGAN: It’s too late. You’re a robot, for goodness’ sake.
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 98
KYLE: My positronic brain is seventy times more complex than the human brain. Any emotion you can feel, I can feel.
TEGAN: When will you get it into your head, you don’t love me! You just think you do. It’s like... you’ve got your wires crossed.
KYLE: I wish it was that simple.
TEGAN: Can’t you just reprogramme yourself to forget about me?
KYLE: No. I can’t.
TEGAN: If you genuinely loved me, you would.
KYLE: It’s because I love you that I can’t.
TEGAN: Please. Anyone, if they had a switch in their head that could make them stop loving the wrong person, would flip that switch.
KYLE: You think I’m just a machine? But it’s the fact that I’m capable of love that means I’m alive.
TEGAN: It’s up to you. Either way, once this is over, I never want to see you again. You’re not to look for me, and if we’re ever in the same room, act like I’m not there.
KYLE: If that’s what you want.
TEGAN: Don’t put it on me. I’m not saying this because it’s what I want but because it’s what’s best - for both of us.
KYLE: Yes. Agreed.
TEGAN: Then I think we’re done.
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 99
KYLE: Yes. I just wanted to let you know, I’m sorry.
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 100
GLAUBER: Working late, sir?
POLSBROEK: Evidently. What can I do for you, Captain?
GLAUBER: There’s a gentleman at the gate, sir.
POLSBROEK: A gentleman?
GLAUBER: The Doctor. Didn’t give a surname, although I enquired repeatedly.
POLSBROEK: Send him away, I’m busy...
GLAUBER: I would have, sir, except that he claims he is a time- traveller, come to collect the Countess.
POLSBROEK: What? Then bring him here at once.
GLAUBER: (LEAVING) Yes, sir. Right away!
GLAUBER: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 101
REMBRANDT: Sorry, I didn’t expect anyone to still be down here...
NYSSA: No, it’s alright. I was just.. waiting for the dawn.
REMBRANDT: Do you mind if I wait with you?
NYSSA: You can’t sleep either?
REMBRANDT: No. I haven’t been able to sleep for a long time.
NYSSA: It must be very worrying, to be in financial difficulty.
REMBRANDT: It is out of my hands. My humiliation awaits. Forty years, of toiling every hour God sent and I have nothing to show for it. My only hope is to save some money for my son, and enough for a small place in the West Quarter.
NYSSA: What if I told you that in the future, your work will be highly valued, and highly regarded?
REMBRANDT: Then I would ask you what use it was to me, to know that others will profit from my labour? What comfort is it for me to know that I will be highly regarded after my death?
NYSSA: I just thought -
REMBRANDT: I’d like my rewards now, not when I’m lying in my grave.
NYSSA: What about your reputation?
REMBRANDT: My good name has been ruined by that madwoman Geertje, who has stolen from me, and slandered me. I am beyond redemption.
REMBRANDT: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 102
NYSSA: And that’s why you sit alone in the dark?
REMBRANDT: No, I sit alone in the dark because... in the darkness, I feel close to Saskia.
NYSSA: Your wife?
REMBRANDT: In the shadows and shapes that form in the flicker of the candlelight... it’s as if she’s still here beside me.
NYSSA: You must miss her terribly.
REMBRANDT: People say that, but that’s not how it feels. It feels like she’s always in the next room, just out of sight.
NYSSA: The dead are always with us, in our memories and our dreams.
REMBRANDT: That’s why I can’t sleep. Because in my dream I’1l forget she’s dead, then I’1ll wake up - (BREAKS DOWN) - and remember.
NYSSA: It’s hard. I’ve lost people dear to me. More than you could ever know.
REMBRANDT: She was my life. What am I supposed to do when my reason for living is gone? I go on, yes, I get up in the morning, I work, I eat, I drink, I go to bed. It never gets any easier.
NYSSA: No, it doesn’t get any easier. You just grow accustomed to the pain.
NYSSA: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 103
POLSBROEK: Countess, may I present... the Doctor.
DOCTOR: (ENTERS) Good morning. I understand you’ve gone to a great deal of trouble to bring me here.
TELDAK: Thank you, Polsbroek. That will be all.
POLSBROEK: Countess.
TELDAK: Doctor. You find me alone, stranded and under threat of death.
DOCTOR: Yes, my friend told me what happened. But you’ve arranged for a Spaceship to be built, and very impressive it is too. So why do you need me?
TELDAK: Why a time-traveller, you mean?
DOCTOR: Yes.
TELDAK: Is it not obvious? The Nix invaded my home world. With a time- machine, that could be averted.
DOCTOR: That’s quite a big thing to ask.
TELDAK: Or at least more of my people could be saved.
DOCTOR: I’m afraid I can’t.
TELDAK: “Can't”? Because it is a physical impossibility - or because you do not wish to?
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR: The past has been written. Any attempt to change the course of established history will result in disaster... Believe me, it’s been tried.
TELDAK: I understand. I am in no position to make demands. But you realise that while I remain on Earth, the Nix will continue to pose a threat to the indigenous life.
DOCTOR: So either I help you or more innocent people will die.
TELDAK: No. If you refuse, I will submit myself to the justice of the Nix and allow them to execute me.
DOCTOR: So. If I agree... where do you want to go?
TELDAK: All I desire is see my home one last time before I die. Is that too much to ask?
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 105
TELDAK: INCOHERENTLY, SINISTER SPLOSHING.
REMBRANDT: It’s almost as if the rain is trying to get in.
KYLE: (ENTERING) It is.
REMBRANDT: What? I don’t understand.
TEGAN: (ENTERING) The Nix. Are all the windows closed? All the shutters?
REMBRANDT: Yes, I expect so. Sorry, what are the Nix?
NYSSA: Malevolent water-spirits from another world.
REMBRANDT: Oh, right, that makes - What did you say?
KYLE: They know that Tegan, Nyssa and I have been in contact with the Countess. They won’t be able to detect her, so they’1l have tracked us down instead.
TEGAN: In the hope that we will bring her out of hiding?
KYLE: That she will surrender herself to save us, yes.
TEGAN: And will she?
NYSSA: It’s seeping in through the ceiling.
NYSSA: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 106
REMBRANDT: But that’s impossible, I’ve only just had the roof re-grouted.
NYSSA: It’s not impossible if the water is acting as a medium for an alien life-form.
REMBRANDT: Oh. This is why I only work with oils!
TEGAN: But you can ward them off, right, Kyle? Use your dispersion ray, whatever it was?
KYLE: Up to a point.
TEGAN: What?
KYLE: I only have limited power. I can’t hold them back forever.
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 107
TELDAK: Well, Doctor, do you agree?
DOCTOR: To take you home? Yes. My craft isn’t far.
TELDAK: I know. I had it transferred here.
DOCTOR: You are eager to leave. But I’1l need to pick up my friends First.
TELDAK: If they had stayed here I would have been able to conceal them
TELDAK: from the Nix. Now, I sense they have been detected...
DOCTOR: What? Then I must warn them!
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 108
OPEN: UNDER THE FORCE OF STORM.
NYSSA: Watch out! The window!
KYLE: Behind me, all of you. Behind me!
TEGAN: There’s more of them!
REMBRANDT: And I thought my life couldn’t get any worse.
KYLE: It’s about to.
TEGAN: What?
KYLE: (WEAK, EFFORT) I need time to recharge. Only enough energy for two more bursts. Then -
DOCTOR: (BURSTING IN) Ah! There you all are! I thought you might be in trouble.
DOCTOR: And it turns out I was completely right.
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 109
NYSSA: Doctor, Kyle’s been keeping them back, but -
DOCTOR: He’s running low on juice. We should get out of here. Kyle, can you clear us a path?
KYLE: I think so.
DOCTOR: Alright. Ready, all of you. When I say run, run. Now!
DOCTOR: Run!!!
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 110
DOCTOR: THEN HALT AT A BRIDGE.
TEGAN: Where are we going?
DOCTOR: East India House.
KYLE: But the Nix will follow us there.
DOCTOR: Then we’d better hurry. Rembrandt?
REMBRANDT: Yes, Doctor?
DOCTOR: The Nix are only interested in us. Keep your head down and they should leave you alone.
REMBRANDT: Then good luck, Doctor. And your friends.
DOCTOR: Yes, and you too. Keep up the good work. Must dash!
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 111
POLSBROEK: This... structure is the means by which you will leave us?
TELDAK: It is so much more than it appears. Only the most advanced technology could appear so mundane.
POLSBROEK: Countess. Will I ever see you again?
TELDAK: All being well, Polsbroek, this is the end. And no-one regrets that more than I. (KISSES HIM) You understand what you must do?
POLSBROEK: I do.
TELDAK: Then I will be leaving this world in safe hands. Your hands. Let that be my parting gift. A bold new future!
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 112
GLAUBER: Who goes there!
DOCTOR: It’s me, the Doctor.
GLAUBER: And your two lady-friends. How lovely to be reacquainted.
TEGAN: For you, maybe.
NYSSA: We have to get inside.
KYLE: Nyssa’s right, the Nix are closing in.
DOCTOR: Captain Glauber, if you could -
GLAUBER: Indeed, Doctor. In you go.
GLAUBER: My Arquebusiers will stand guard.
TEGAN: Against the Nix? Armed with muskets?
GLAUBER: The Mayor has ordered us to defend this building to the last man.
KYLE: And there they are.
TEGAN: (HORRIFIED) There’s dozens of them.
DOCTOR: Quick! Everyone! Inside!
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 113
GLAUBER: Men! You know what to do. Ready arms. Take aim. Fire!
GLAUBER: Hold positions! Take aim! Fire!
GLAUBER: We do not retreat. We do not show fear. We are Dutchmen and if necessary we will die like Dutchmen! ..Fire!
GLAUBER: You shall not enter. Not while there is breath in my body -
ARE: DROWNING UNDERWATER ALONG WITH HIM.
ARE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 114
TELDAK: Doctor, I see you —- (are)
DOCTOR: No time for niceties. Are you ready to leave?
TELDAK: Of course, yes.
DOCTOR: Then inside, all of you! Chop chop!
TEGAN: Why the mad rush?
NYSSA: Because the sooner we leave, the sooner the Nix will give up.
KYLE: Deactivating genetic shield.
DOCTOR: Good. Now they’1ll detect you leaving, Countess.
TELDAK: Farewell, Polsbroek.
POLSBROEK: Farewell.
POLSBROEK: May you find the atonement you desire.
POLSBROEK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 115
DOCTOR: Setting course for Corus-Valletine, as requested.
TELDAK: We are not travelling in time?
DOCTOR: No. You’1l just have to take it as you find it.
NYSSA: Maybe the Nix will have given up their attack.
TELDAK: I think that... unlikely.
TEGAN: But there might be some of your people still alive, somewhere.
TEGAN: You can’t give up hope.
TELDAK: You are right. I am not giving up.
DOCTOR: Geostationary orbit should do it...
TELDAK: So. I shall set eyes on my world once more. At last.
TEGAN: (POLITELY DELIVERING BAD NEWS) It’s very... blue.
DOCTOR: No signs of life. I’m sorry.
TELDAK: The handiwork of the Nix. My world has been flooded, its destroyed. I am the last of the Vorax.
TEGAN: You can’t be sure of that.
TEGAN: people
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 116
TELDAK: Oh no. I am sure.
KYLE: Ours was the only ship to escape.
NYSSA: You’ve known all along, that you were the only survivor?
TELDAK: The sole custodian of the legacy of my race.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry. But I can’t change anything. History has been written.
TELDAK: I realise that, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I can drop you off somewhere quiet, if you like -
TELDAK: No, Doctor. You will take me back to Earth.
TEGAN: Earth? What do you want to go back there for?
TELDAK: Not to the time I left. To the future. Kyle?
KYLE: The year 1983.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure that’s a terribly good idea.
TELDAK: I am not asking, Doctor. You will do as I say.
KYLE: Or Nyssa will die.
TEGAN: What the -! Kyle!
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 117
KYLE: I’m sorry, Tegan. But my allegiance is to the Countess.
TELDAK: (LAUGHS) He is my servant, more than yours.
DOCTOR: Countess, whatever you intend -
TELDAK: One word from me and Kyle will project an energy wave, and your friend will be dead. One word!
DOCTOR: It won’t work. The TARDIS exists in a state of temporal grace.
KYLE: The Doctor is lying. I know from Tegan’s memory that energy weapons can be fired in the TARDIS.
DOCTOR: Alright, alright. Just let Nyssa go.
TELDAK: I will. When I no longer require your co-operation.
DOCTOR: There won’t be anything for you in 1983, you know. They’ve only
DOCTOR: just invented the integrated circuit.
TELDAK: We shall see.
DOCTOR: Amsterdam, 1983. As requested.
TELDAK: You, Tegan. Open the doors.
TEGAN: You’re not the boss of me.
TELDAK: Open the doors - or Kyle will kill Nyssa.
TEGAN: Kyle wouldn’t. Would you, Kyle?
TEGAN: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 118
KYLE: I’m sorry, Tegan. Please. Just open the doors.
TELDAK: Now. Outside. All of you!
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 119
TELDAK: RIVERSIDE, DISTANT BIRDS. DOCTOR AND FRIENDS EMERGE.
TEGAN: I don’t believe it.
NYSSA: This isn’t the city we left.
DOCTOR: I’m very much afraid it is.
TEGAN: What? With airships and giant radio masts?
KYLE: Those aren’t airships. Don’t you recognise them?
DOCTOR: Rembrandt’s drawings! Brought to life.
TELDAK: Humanity has been industrious in our absence.
DOCTOR: Busy? The whole course of history has been - (changed)
FANFARE: VIA A LOUDSPEAKER.
MODERN POLSBROEK: (D)
MODERN POLSBROEK: Seeking work? Then why not apply for one of the North Venus colonies? Visit your nearest recruitment office for details. Remember, you’re all part of the company. The Dutch Galactic Company!
TEGAN: That was the Mayor!
NYSSA: More likely his descendant.
DOCTOR: It seems the East India company have expanded their horizons. Countess. You knew this would happen?
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 120
TELDAK: All part of my plan. You see, I left instructions, anticipating
TELDAK: my eventual return.
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 121
MODERN GLAUBER: Burgemeister Polsbroek?
MODERN POLSBROEK: Yes, what is it?
MODERN GLAUBER: You’re not going to believe it, sir... but she has returned, exactly as predicted.
MODERN POLSBROEK: The Countess Mach-Teldak?
MODERN: GLAUBER?: Her arrival was detected in the Centrum sector five minutes ago.
MODERN POLSBROEK: Dispatch a watch-droid. Have her brought here at once.
MODERN GLAUBER: (FX: CLICKS HEELS) Yes, sir.
MODERN POLSBROEK: So after three hundred years, the Countess has finally returned to us...
MODERN POLSBROEK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 122
TEGAN: You mean she’s deliberately changed history?
DOCTOR: Yes. The Countess left instructions in order to accelerate the human race’s technological development.
NYSSA: To the point where they could colonise other worlds?
KYLE: Not just colonise.
TELDAK: If they have followed my instructions, there should be an entire fleet in orbit. And at my command, they will voyage to the Nix homeworld - and wipe it from existence!
DOCTOR: Revenge. This is all about revenge!
TELDAK: They destroyed my world. So I will destroy theirs.
DROID: Countess Mach-Teldak. Your arrival has been expected.
TELDAK: Indeed?
DROID: Burgemeister Polsbroek sends his warm regards and invites you to join him in Galactic Company House.
TELDAK: Inform him I am on my way.
TELDAK: But before I go. One last thing. Doctor. You will give me the
TELDAK: key to the TARDIS.
DOCTOR: And why would I do that?
DOCTOR: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)
TELDAK: Because now that I have created this timeline,
TELDAK: Page 123
TELDAK: I have no wish
TELDAK: for you to undo it. You and your TARDIS will remain here with
TELDAK: me.
DOCTOR: I’m afraid I can’t let you have it.
TELDAK: No?
DOCTOR: You’ve already done enough damage. I’m not going to enable you
DOCTOR: to wreak havoc through all of time and space.
TELDAK: I can see I’m going to have to demonstrate that I don’t make
TELDAK: idle threats. Kylex. Kill Nyssa.
KYLE: Yes, countess.
NYSSA: What?
TEGAN: You can’t. Kyle. If you love me, if you ever loved me -
KYLE: I do but - (MOMENT OF DOUBT, THEN CERTAINTY) I’m sorry, Tegan.
KYLE: I serve the Countess.
DOCTOR: No, please, listen, I’1ll give you the key —
TELDAK: Too late, Doctor. Kill her!
TEGAN: What have you done? What have you done!
DOCTOR: (RUSHING TO HELP HER) Nyssa!
TELDAK: (OVER PRECEDING LINE) Kylex. Confirm the female’s status.
TELDAK: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 124
KYLE: Status confirmed. The girl Nyssa is dead.
KYLE: END OF PART THREE
KYLE: THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 125

elements.text: PART FOUR
FX: ENERGY WAVE. NYSSA COLLAPSES.
BRIEF GASP AS SHE LOSES CONSCIOUSNESS
What have you done? What have you done!
(RUSHING TO HELP HER) Nyssa!
(OVER PRECEDING LINE) Kylex. Confirm the female’s status.
FX: WHIRR OF SCAN.
Status confirmed. The girl Nyssa is dead.
SCENE CONTINUES:
69. EXT. ALTERNATIVE AMSTERDAM DOCKS [CONTINUOUS]
(DISTRAUGHT) No. No. (ACCUSATORY) Kyle.
Tegan -
He killed her.
Make one move and I’11 order him to kill you too.
Then why don’t you?
Countess. The Doctor is the only one who can pilot the TARDIS. And we can use Tegan as leverage.
I’ll give you leverage!
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 126
Tegan. Please. Getting angry won’t bring Nyssa back.
Very true. Doctor, the TARDIS key?
(HANDING IT OVER) Try not to lose it.
I’1ll do my best. (TO DROID) Watch-robot? I wish for this man
and woman to be placed in custody. Can you oblige?
FX: DROID CHIRPS.
Your request is accepted by Burgemeister Polsbroek.
them to Galactic Company House.
Excellent. Kylex -
I will dispose of the girl’s body and join you.
Conscientious as ever. (BEAT) Alright. Watch-robot,
FX: DROID WHIRRS, THEY MOVE AWAY DURING FOLLOWING:
Move! Do not make any unpredictable movements! Move!
MUSIC LINK.
I will take
lead on!
Move!
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 127
70. INT. FUTURISTIC CONTROL ROOM
FX: DOOR SWISHES OPEN. TELDAK ENTERS.
Countess!
Burgemeister Polsbroek, I presume?
This is a great honour. Ever since you left, over three centuries ago, my family have complied with your wishes.
I am pleased that my faith in your ancestor was not misplaced.
Not at all. We have never forgotten the trust you placed in us. There is so much for you to see, the domed colonies on Mars and Venus, and moons -
In time, I will be delighted to inspect your achievements. But first, I must know. I left your ancestor with instructions to build a space fleet.
FX: BUTTON PRESSED. MONITOR ON.
A thousand ships capable of interstellar flight are moored in
geostationary orbit. I trust they are to your satisfaction?
Oh, they are, Burgemeister Polsbroek. They are indeed!
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 128
71. INT. CELL
FX: DOOR CLANGS SHUT.
So what do we do now?
Well, Kyle seems to have convinced the Countess to keep us alive... For now.
What good does that do?
Brave heart, Tegan.
Nyssa’s dead, and that’s all you can say?
No. But whatever I do say will never be quite enough.
It’s not your fault. Kyle got us into this. Though I feel like the world’s biggest idiot for letting myself get taken in by him.
FX: DOCTOR GETS UP, TAPS WALL.
(CHANGING SUBJECT) You know, it’s times like these, I really wonder why I haven’t built myself another sonic screwdriver -
FX: DOOR OPENS.
What are you doing here?
Tegan -
Get out.
Please, just give me a chance -
I said go. You killed my best friend!
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 129
Look, you have to come with me. Both of you.
THE WATERS OF AMSTERDAM by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 130
